p: While the sampling points do appear clustered in some areas (Figs 1 and 2), spatial autocorrelation was not deemed a significant concern in the current study. It has been argued that spatial autocorrelation in species distribution models is a concern when, for example, ecological or evolutionary processes prevent taxa from shifting their distributions [ 40]. For both N. rafflesiana and N. tentaculata, their relatively widespread observed occurrences suggest that such processes have not exerted strong constraints on these species shifting their distributions over time.
